Religious sacrificial ceremonies

Since ancient times, have the emperors and kings who received the mandate of heaven ever failed to perform the feng and shan sacrifices? There have been cases where they performed the rituals without receiving the appropriate omens, but never have there been cases where auspicious signs appeared and they did not proceed to Mount Tai. Even those who received the mandate but whose achievements were insufficient, or those who reached Mount Li but whose virtue was not all-encompassing, or those whose virtue was all-encompassing but who lacked sufficient time - these are the reasons why the rituals were performed rarely. The Classic says: 'If for three years the rites are not performed, the rites will surely be abolished; if for three years the music is not performed, the music will surely be ruined.' In times of flourishing dynasties, the feng and shan sacrifices respond accordingly; in times of decline, they cease. The longest gaps lasted over a thousand years, the shortest several hundred years, so their ceremonies have become lost and obscured, and their details can no longer be recorded or transmitted.

The Classic says that Shun, using the jade disks and jade staff, aligned the seven celestial bodies. He then offered sacrifices to the Supreme Deity, made offerings to the Six Honored Ones, gazed upon the mountains and rivers, and paid respects to all the spirits. He gathered the five auspicious symbols, chose an auspicious month and day, met with the four mountain lords and the regional governors, and returned the symbols. In the second month, he toured the east, arriving at Mount Dai. Mount Dai is Mount Tai. He made burnt offerings and gazed in order upon the mountains and rivers. He then held court with the eastern lords. The eastern lords were the feudal lords. He harmonized the seasons, months, and days; unified the pitch pipes, measures, and weights; and refined the five rites with five jades, three silks, two living creatures, and one dead offering. In the fifth month, he toured to the southern peak. The southern peak is Mount Heng. In the eighth month, he toured to the western peak. The western peak is Mount Hua. In the eleventh month, he toured to the northern peak. The northern peak is Mount Heng. All followed the same rituals as at Mount Dai. The central peak is Mount Song. He toured once every five years.
3
ç¦¹éµä¹‹ã€‚ å¾Œåå››ä¸–ï¼Œè‡³å¸å­”ç”²ï¼Œæ·«å¾·å¥½ç¥ï¼Œç¥ç€†ï¼ŒäºŒé¾å»ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œä¸‰ä¸–ï¼Œæ¹¯ä¼æ¡€ï¼Œæ¬²é·å¤ç¤¾ï¼Œä¸å¯ï¼Œä½œå¤ç¤¾ã€‚ å¾Œå…«ä¸–ï¼Œè‡³å¸å¤ªæˆŠï¼Œæœ‰æ¡‘è°·ç”Ÿæ–¼å»·ï¼Œä¸€æš®å¤§æ‹±ï¼Œæ‡¼ã€‚ ä¼Šé™Ÿæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¦–ä¸å‹å¾·ã€‚ã€ å¤ªæˆŠä¿®å¾·ï¼Œæ¡‘è°·æ­»ã€‚ ä¼Šé™Ÿè´Šå·«å’¸ï¼Œå·«å’¸ä¹‹èˆˆè‡ªæ­¤å§‹ã€‚ å¾Œåå››ä¸–ï¼Œå¸æ­¦ä¸å¾—å‚…èªªç‚ºç›¸ï¼Œæ®·å¾©èˆˆç„‰ï¼Œç¨±é«˜å®—ã€‚ æœ‰é›‰ç™»é¼è€³é›Šï¼Œæ­¦ä¸æ‡¼ã€‚ ç¥–å·±æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¿®å¾·ã€‚ã€ æ­¦ä¸å¾ä¹‹ï¼Œä½ä»¥æ°¸å¯§ã€‚ å¾Œäº”ä¸–ï¼Œå¸æ­¦ä¹™æ…¢ç¥è€Œéœ‡æ­»ã€‚ å¾Œä¸‰ä¸–ï¼Œå¸ç´‚æ·«äº‚ï¼Œæ­¦ç‹ä¼ä¹‹ã€‚ ç”±æ­¤è§€ä¹‹ï¼Œå§‹æœªå˜—ä¸è‚…ç¥—ï¼Œå¾Œç¨æ€ æ…¢ä¹Ÿã€‚
Yu followed these practices. Fourteen generations later, during the reign of Emperor Kong Jia, his virtue became decadent and he favored spirits excessively, so the spirits abandoned him, and two dragons departed. Three generations later, Tang attacked Jie and wanted to move the Xia altar, but it could not be moved, so he created a Xia altar. Eight generations later, during the reign of Emperor Tai Wu, a mulberry tree and a grain plant grew in the courtyard, growing to the size of a large embrace overnight, which frightened him. Yi Zhi said: 'Monsters cannot overcome virtue.' Tai Wu cultivated virtue, and the mulberry and grain died. Yi Zhi praised Wu Xian, and Wu Xian's rise began from this time. Fourteen generations later, Emperor Wu Ding obtained Fu Yue as his chancellor, and Yin was revived, and he was called Gao Zong. A pheasant perched on the cauldron's handle and crowed, which frightened Wu Ding. Zu Ji said: 'Cultivate virtue.' Wu Ding followed this advice, and his position was permanently secure. Five generations later, Emperor Wu Yi offended the spirits and was killed by lightning. Three generations later, Emperor Zhou was decadent and chaotic, and King Wu attacked him. From this we can see that at the beginning they were never irreverent toward the spirits, but later they gradually became negligent.
4
å‘¨å®˜æ›°ï¼Œå†¬æ—¥è‡³ï¼Œç¥€å¤©æ–¼å—éƒŠï¼Œè¿é•·æ—¥ä¹‹è‡³ï¼› å¤æ—¥è‡³ï¼Œç¥­åœ°ç¥—ã€‚ çš†ç”¨æ¨‚èˆï¼Œè€Œç¥ä¹ƒå¯å¾—è€Œç¦®ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤©å­ç¥­å¤©ä¸‹åå±±å¤§å·ï¼Œäº”å¶½è¦–ä¸‰å…¬ï¼Œå››ç€†è¦–è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯ç¥­å…¶ç–†å…§åå±±å¤§å·ã€‚ å››ç€†è€…ï¼Œæ±Ÿã€æ²³ã€æ·®ã€æ¿Ÿä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤©å­æ›°æ˜å ‚ã€è¾Ÿé›ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æ›°æ³®å®®ã€‚
The Zhou officials said that on the winter solstice, they sacrificed to heaven in the southern suburbs to welcome the lengthening days; on the summer solstice, they sacrificed to the earth spirits. They all used music and dance, and only then could the spirits be approached and the rites performed. The Son of Heaven sacrificed to the famous mountains and great rivers of the realm. The Five Peaks were treated like the Three Dukes, the Four Rivers like the feudal lords, and the feudal lords sacrificed to the famous mountains and great rivers within their territories. The Four Rivers are the Yangtze, Yellow River, Huai, and Ji. The Son of Heaven called it the Bright Hall and the Universal School, the feudal lords called it the Half Moon Palace.

å‘¨å…¬æ—¢ç›¸æˆç‹ï¼ŒéƒŠç¥€åç¨·ä»¥é…å¤©ï¼Œå®—ç¥€æ–‡ç‹æ–¼æ˜å ‚ä»¥é…ä¸Šå¸ã€‚ è‡ªç¦¹èˆˆè€Œä¿®ç¤¾ç¥€ï¼Œåç¨·ç¨¼ç©¡ï¼Œæ•…æœ‰ç¨·ç¥ ï¼ŒéƒŠç¤¾æ‰€å¾ä¾†å°šçŸ£ã€‚
After the Duke of Zhou assisted King Cheng, he performed suburban sacrifices to Hou Ji to match heaven, and ancestral sacrifices to King Wen in the Bright Hall to match the Supreme Deity. Since Yu rose and established the altar sacrifices, and Hou Ji farmed, there were grain sacrifices, and the origins of suburban and altar sacrifices go back to ancient times.
6
è‡ªå‘¨å…‹æ®·å¾Œåå››ä¸–ï¼Œä¸–ç›Šè¡°ï¼Œç¦®æ¨‚å»¢ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æ£è¡Œï¼Œè€Œå¹½ç‹ç‚ºçŠ¬æˆæ‰€æ•—ï¼Œå‘¨æ±å¾™é›’é‚‘ã€‚ ç§¦è¥„å…¬æ”»æˆæ•‘å‘¨ï¼Œå§‹åˆ—ç‚ºè«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ ç§¦è¥„å…¬æ—¢ä¾¯ï¼Œå±…è¥¿å‚ï¼Œè‡ªä»¥ç‚ºä¸»å°‘çšä¹‹ç¥ï¼Œä½œè¥¿ç•¤ï¼Œç¥ ç™½å¸ï¼Œå…¶ç‰²ç”¨é¨®é§’é»ƒç‰›ç¾ç¾Šå„ä¸€äº‘ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œåå…­å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ–‡å…¬æ±çµæ±§æ¸­ä¹‹é–’ï¼Œåœå±…ä¹‹è€Œå‰ã€‚ æ–‡å…¬å¤¢é»ƒè›‡è‡ªå¤©ä¸‹å±¬åœ°ï¼Œå…¶å£æ­¢æ–¼é„œè¡ã€‚ æ–‡å…¬å•å²æ•¦ï¼Œæ•¦æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤ä¸Šå¸ä¹‹å¾µï¼Œå›å…¶ç¥ ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ä½œé„œç•¤ï¼Œç”¨ä¸‰ç‰²éƒŠç¥­ç™½å¸ç„‰ã€‚
After the Zhou conquered Yin, fourteen generations passed, and the dynasty gradually declined. Rites and music were abandoned, the feudal lords acted wantonly, and King You was defeated by the Dog Rong, so the Zhou moved east to Luoyi. Duke Xiang of Qin attacked the Rong to save Zhou, and began to be ranked among the feudal lords. After Duke Xiang of Qin became a feudal lord, he resided in the western frontier. Considering himself the descendant of Shaohao's spirit, he built the Western Altar, sacrificing to the White Emperor, using a sorrel horse, yellow ox, and ram as offerings. Sixteen years later, Duke Wen of Qin hunted east between the Qian and Wei rivers, and divination showed it was auspicious to settle there. Duke Wen dreamed of a yellow serpent descending from heaven to earth, its mouth stopping at Fu Yan. Duke Wen asked Shi Dun, who said: 'This is an omen from the Supreme Deity. Your lordship should sacrifice to it.' Therefore he built the Fu Altar, using the three sacrificial animals to perform suburban sacrifices to the White Emperor.
7
è‡ªæœªä½œé„œç•¤ä¹Ÿï¼Œè€Œé›æ—æ•…æœ‰å³é™½æ­¦ç•¤ï¼Œé›æ±æœ‰å¥½ç•¤ï¼Œçš†å»¢ç„¡ç¥ ã€‚ æˆ–æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡ªå¤ä»¥é›å·ç©é«˜ï¼Œç¥æ˜ä¹‹éš©ï¼Œæ•…ç«‹ç•¤éƒŠä¸Šå¸ï¼Œè«¸ç¥ç¥ çš†èšäº‘ã€‚ è“‹é»ƒå¸æ™‚å˜—ç”¨äº‹ï¼Œé›–æ™šå‘¨äº¦éƒŠç„‰ã€‚ã€ å…¶èªä¸ç¶“è¦‹ï¼Œç¸‰ç´³è€…ä¸é“ã€‚
Before building the Fu Altar, there were already the Wu Yang Wu Altar beside Yong, and the Hao Altar east of Yong, but all were abandoned without sacrifices. Some say: 'Since ancient times, Yong province has accumulated height and is a secluded place for spirits, so altars were established to sacrifice to the Supreme Deity, and all the spirit sacrifices were gathered there. It is said that during the Yellow Emperor's time they performed the rituals, and even in the late Zhou they performed suburban sacrifices.' These words are not found in the classics, and the educated do not discuss them.
8
ä½œé„œç•¤å¾Œä¹å¹´ï¼Œæ–‡å…¬ç²è‹¥çŸ³é›²ï¼Œäºé™³å€‰åŒ—é˜ªåŸç¥ ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¶ç¥æˆ–æ­²ä¸è‡³ï¼Œæˆ–æ­²æ•¸ä¾†ï¼Œä¾†ä¹Ÿå¸¸ä»¥å¤œï¼Œå…‰è¼è‹¥æµæ˜Ÿï¼Œå¾æ±å—ä¾†é›†äºç¥ åŸï¼Œå‰‡è‹¥é›„é›ï¼Œå…¶è²æ®·é›²ï¼Œé‡é›å¤œé›Šã€‚ ä»¥ä¸€ç‰¢ç¥ ï¼Œå‘½æ›°é™³å¯¶ã€‚
Nine years after building the Fu Altar, Duke Wen obtained a stone like clouds at Chen Cang's northern slope and built a city to sacrifice to it. Its spirit sometimes did not come for a year, sometimes came several times. When it came, it was always at night, its brilliance like a shooting star, coming from the southeast to gather at the sacrificial city, making sounds like a male pheasant, with a resounding echo like wild chickens crowing at night. He sacrificed with one pen of animals, naming it Chen Bao.
9
ä½œé„œç•¤å¾Œä¸ƒåå…«å¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¾·å…¬æ—¢ç«‹ï¼Œåœå±…é›ï¼Œã€Œå¾Œå­å­«é£²é¦¬æ–¼æ²³ã€ï¼Œé‚éƒ½é›ã€‚ é›ä¹‹è«¸ç¥ è‡ªæ­¤èˆˆã€‚ ç”¨ä¸‰ç™¾ç‰¢æ–¼é„œç•¤ã€‚ ä½œä¼ç¥ ã€‚ ç£”ç‹—é‚‘å››é–€ï¼Œä»¥å¾¡è ±è‘ã€‚
Seventy-eight years after building the Fu Altar, Duke De of Qin ascended the throne. He divined about settling in Yong: 'Later generations will drink horses at the river,' so he moved the capital to Yong. The various sacrifices of Yong flourished from this time. He used three hundred pens of animals at the Fu Altar. He established the Hidden Sacrifice. He tore dogs at the four gates of the city to ward off calamities.
10
å¾·å…¬ç«‹äºŒå¹´å’ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œï¼ˆå…­ï¼‰ï¼»å››ï¼½å¹´ï¼Œç§¦å®£å…¬ä½œå¯†ç•¤æ–¼æ¸­å—ï¼Œç¥­é’å¸ã€‚
Duke De died in his second year. Four years later, Duke Xuan of Qin built the Mi Altar south of the Wei River, sacrificing to the Blue Emperor.
11
å…¶å¾Œåå››å¹´ï¼Œç§¦ç¹†å…¬ç«‹ï¼Œç—…è‡¥äº”æ—¥ä¸å¯¤ï¼› å¯¤ï¼Œä¹ƒè¨€å¤¢è¦‹ä¸Šå¸ï¼Œä¸Šå¸å‘½ç¹†å…¬å¹³æ™‰äº‚ã€‚ å²æ›¸è€Œè¨˜è—ä¹‹åºœã€‚ è€Œå¾Œä¸–çš†æ›°ç§¦ç¹†å…¬ä¸Šå¤©ã€‚
Fourteen years later, Duke Mu of Qin ascended the throne. He fell ill and lay unconscious for five days; when he awoke, he said he dreamed of the Supreme Deity, who commanded Duke Mu to pacify the Jin disorder. The scribe recorded and stored it in the archives. Later generations all said Duke Mu of Qin ascended to heaven.
12
ç§¦ç¹†å…¬å³ä½ä¹å¹´ï¼Œé½Šæ¡“å…¬æ—¢éœ¸ï¼Œæœƒè«¸ä¾¯æ–¼è‘µä¸˜ï¼Œè€Œæ¬²å°ç¦ªã€‚ ç®¡ä»²æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤è€…å°æ³°å±±ç¦ªæ¢çˆ¶è€…ä¸ƒåäºŒå®¶ï¼Œè€Œå¤·å¾æ‰€è¨˜è€…åæœ‰äºŒç„‰ã€‚ æ˜”ç„¡æ‡·æ°å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› è™™ç¾²å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› ç¥è¾²å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› ç‚å¸å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› é»ƒå¸å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº­äº­ï¼› é¡“é Šå°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› å¸åš³å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› å ¯å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› èˆœå°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› ç¦¹å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªæœƒç¨½ï¼› æ¹¯å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªäº‘äº‘ï¼› å‘¨æˆç‹å°æ³°å±±ï¼Œç¦ªç¤¾é¦–ï¼šçš†å—å‘½ç„¶å¾Œå¾—å°ç¦ªã€‚ã€ æ¡“å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¯¡äººåŒ—ä¼å±±æˆï¼Œéå­¤ç«¹ï¼› è¥¿ä¼å¤§å¤ï¼Œæ¶‰æµæ²™ï¼ŒæŸé¦¬æ‡¸è»Šï¼Œä¸Šå‘è€³ä¹‹å±±ï¼› å—ä¼è‡³å¬é™µï¼Œç™»ç†Šè€³å±±ä»¥æœ›æ±Ÿæ¼¢ã€‚ å…µè»Šä¹‹æœƒä¸‰ï¼Œè€Œä¹˜è»Šä¹‹æœƒå…­ï¼Œä¹åˆè«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œä¸€åŒ¡å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯è«é•æˆ‘ã€‚ æ˜”ä¸‰ä»£å—å‘½ï¼Œäº¦ä½•ä»¥ç•°ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ç®¡ä»²ç¹æ¡“å…¬ä¸å¯çª®ä»¥è¾­ï¼Œå› è¨­ä¹‹ä»¥äº‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ä¹‹å°ç¦ªï¼Œé„—ä¸Šä¹‹é»ï¼ŒåŒ—é‡Œä¹‹ç¦¾ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç‚ºç››ï¼› æ±Ÿæ·®ä¹‹é–’ï¼Œä¸€èŒ…ä¸‰è„Šï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç‚ºè—‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ±æµ·è‡´æ¯”ç›®ä¹‹é­šï¼Œè¥¿æµ·è‡´æ¯”ç¿¼ä¹‹é³¥ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œç‰©æœ‰ä¸å¬è€Œè‡ªè‡³è€…åæœ‰äº”ç„‰ã€‚ ä»Šé³³çš‡éº’éºŸä¸ä¾†ï¼Œå˜‰ç©€ä¸ç”Ÿï¼Œè€Œè“¬è’¿è—œè èŒ‚ï¼Œé´Ÿæ¢Ÿæ•¸è‡³ï¼Œè€Œæ¬²å°ç¦ªï¼Œæ¯‹ä¹ƒä¸å¯ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ–¼æ˜¯æ¡“å…¬ä¹ƒæ­¢ã€‚ æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œç§¦ç¹†å…¬å…§æ™‰å›å¤·å¾ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œä¸‰ç½®æ™‰åœ‹ä¹‹å›ï¼Œå¹³å…¶äº‚ã€‚ ç¹†å…¬ç«‹ä¸‰åä¹å¹´è€Œå’ã€‚
In the ninth year of Duke Mu of Qin's reign, after Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon, he assembled the feudal lords at Kuiqiu and wished to perform the feng and shan sacrifices. Guan Zhong said: 'In ancient times, those who performed the feng sacrifice on Mount Tai and the shan sacrifice on Mount Li numbered seventy-two houses, and I have recorded twelve of them. In ancient times, the Wu Huai clan performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Fu Xi performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Shen Nong performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Yan Di performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Huang Di performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Tingting; Zhuan Xu performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Di Ku performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Yao performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Shun performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; Yu performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Kuaiji; Tang performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Yunyun; King Cheng of Zhou performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Sheshou: all received the mandate before they could perform feng and shan.' Duke Huan said: 'I have attacked the Shan Rong in the north, passing through Gu Zhu; attacked Da Xia in the west, crossed the Flowing Sands, tied horses and hung carriages, ascended Mount Bei'er; attacked south to Zhaoling, ascended Mount Xiong'er to gaze upon the Yangtze and Han rivers. I have assembled chariots three times, assembled carriages six times, united the feudal lords nine times, corrected the realm once, and no feudal lord dares disobey me. How is this different from when the Three Dynasties received the mandate?' Therefore Guan Zhong, seeing that Duke Huan could not be persuaded with words, set forth practical reasons, saying: 'The ancient feng and shan sacrifices used millet from Xiang Shang, grain from Bei Li, which served as the abundance; between the Yangtze and Huai rivers, one thatched hut with three ridges, which served as the mat. The Eastern Sea brought forth the fish with united eyes, the Western Sea brought forth the birds with united wings, and then there were fifteen things that came without being summoned. Now phoenixes and unicorns do not come, auspicious grains do not grow, but thorns and brambles flourish, owls appear frequently, and yet you wish to perform feng and shan - is this not impossible?' Therefore Duke Huan stopped. That year, Duke Mu of Qin welcomed the Jin lord Yi Wu. Afterward he installed three Jin rulers and pacified their disorders. Duke Mu died in his thirty-ninth year.
13
å…¶å¾Œç™¾æœ‰é¤˜å¹´ï¼Œè€Œå­”å­è«–è¿°å…­è—ï¼Œå‚³ç•¥è¨€æ˜“å§“è€Œç‹ï¼Œå°æ³°å±±ç¦ªä¹æ¢çˆ¶è€…ä¸ƒåé¤˜ç‹çŸ£ï¼Œå…¶ä¿è±†ä¹‹ç¦®ä¸ç« ï¼Œè“‹é›£è¨€ä¹‹ã€‚ æˆ–å•ç¦˜ä¹‹èªªï¼Œå­”å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸çŸ¥ã€‚ çŸ¥ç¦˜ä¹‹èªªï¼Œå…¶æ–¼å¤©ä¸‹ä¹Ÿè¦–å…¶æŒã€‚ã€ è©©äº‘ç´‚åœ¨ä½ï¼Œæ–‡ç‹å—å‘½ï¼Œæ”¿ä¸åŠæ³°å±±ã€‚ æ­¦ç‹å…‹æ®·äºŒå¹´ï¼Œå¤©ä¸‹æœªå¯§è€Œå´©ã€‚ çˆ°å‘¨å¾·ä¹‹æ´½ç¶­æˆç‹ï¼Œæˆç‹ä¹‹å°ç¦ªå‰‡è¿‘ä¹‹çŸ£ã€‚ åŠå¾Œé™ªè‡£åŸ·æ”¿ï¼Œå­£æ°æ—…æ–¼æ³°å±±ï¼Œä»²å°¼è­ä¹‹ã€‚
More than a hundred years later, Confucius discussed and transmitted the Six Arts, briefly saying that those who changed surnames and became kings, performing feng on Mount Tai and shan on Mount Li, numbered more than seventy kings, but their sacrificial rituals were not clear, so it is difficult to speak of them. Someone asked about the explanation of the di sacrifice, and Confucius said: 'I do not know. If one knew the explanation of the di sacrifice, it would be like seeing the whole realm in the palm of the hand.' The Poetry says: 'When Zhou was on the throne, King Wen received the mandate, but his administration did not reach Mount Tai.' King Wu conquered Yin in the second year, but the realm was not yet peaceful when he died. Only during King Cheng's time was Zhou virtue fully pervasive, and King Cheng's feng and shan was close to it. When later ministers took power, the Ji clan traveled to Mount Tai, and Confucius criticized them.

At this time, Chang Hong used magical arts to serve King Ling of Zhou, and the feudal lords did not come to court Zhou, so Zhou power was weak. Chang Hong then made clear the affairs of ghosts and spirits, and set up the shooting of fox heads. Fox heads were for the feudal lords who did not come. He relied on strange things to try to bring the feudal lords. The feudal lords did not follow, and the Jin people captured and killed Chang Hong. The Zhou people's discussions of magical oddities began with Chang Hong.

More than a hundred years later, Duke Ling of Qin built the Wu Yang Upper Altar, sacrificing to the Yellow Emperor; built the Lower Altar, sacrificing to the Yan Emperor.

Forty-eight years later, the Zhou Grand Historian Tan met Duke Xian of Qin and said: 'Qin initially merged with Zhou, merged then separated, after five hundred years they should merge again, merge for seventeen years and a hegemon king will emerge.' After Qin Shi Huang unified the realm and became emperor, some said: 'The Yellow Emperor obtained earth virtue, yellow dragons and earthworms appeared. Xia obtained wood virtue, green dragons stopped in the suburbs, grass and trees flourished. Yin obtained metal virtue, silver overflowed from the mountains. Zhou obtained fire virtue, there were symbols of red crows. Now Qin changes Zhou, it is the time of water virtue. Formerly Duke Wen of Qin went hunting and obtained a black dragon, this is the omen of water virtue.' Therefore Qin renamed the river 'Virtue River', made the tenth month of winter the beginning of the year, took black as the superior color, measured with six as the name, took Da LÃ¼ as the superior pitch, and affairs were governed by law.

å³å¸ä½ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ±å·¡éƒ¡ç¸£ï¼Œç¥ é¨¶å¶§å±±ï¼Œé Œç§¦åŠŸæ¥­ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯å¾µå¾é½Šé­¯ä¹‹å„’ç”Ÿåšå£«ä¸ƒåäººï¼Œè‡³ä¹æ³°å±±ä¸‹ã€‚ è«¸å„’ç”Ÿæˆ–è­°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤è€…å°ç¦ªç‚ºè’²è»Šï¼Œæƒ¡å‚·å±±ä¹‹åœŸçŸ³è‰æœ¨ï¼› åŸ½åœ°è€Œç¥­ï¼Œå¸­ç”¨è‘…ç¨­ï¼Œè¨€å…¶æ˜“éµä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å§‹çš‡èæ­¤è­°å„ä¹–ç•°ï¼Œé›£æ–½ç”¨ï¼Œç”±æ­¤çµ€å„’ç”Ÿã€‚ è€Œé‚é™¤è»Šé“ï¼Œä¸Šè‡ªæ³°å±±é™½è‡³å·”ï¼Œç«‹çŸ³é Œç§¦å§‹çš‡å¸å¾·ï¼Œæ˜å…¶å¾—å°ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¾é™°é“ä¸‹ï¼Œç¦ªæ–¼æ¢çˆ¶ã€‚ å…¶ç¦®é —é‡‡å¤ªç¥ä¹‹ç¥€é›ä¸Šå¸æ‰€ç”¨ï¼Œè€Œå°è—çš†ç¥•ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸–ä¸å¾—è€Œè¨˜ä¹Ÿã€‚
In the third year of his imperial position, he toured east through the commanderies and counties, sacrificed at Zouyi Mountain, praising Qin's achievements. Therefore he summoned seventy Confucian scholars and doctors from Qi and Lu to the foot of Mount Tai. Some Confucian scholars discussed: 'In ancient times, for the feng sacrifice they used cattail wagons to avoid harming the mountain's soil, stones, and vegetation; they swept the ground and sacrificed, using mats of straw, speaking of how easy it was to follow.' Shi Huang heard these discussions were all different, difficult to implement, so he dismissed the Confucian scholars. He then cleared the road, ascending from the sunny side of Mount Tai to the peak, erected a stone to praise Qin Shi Huang's virtue, making clear that he obtained the feng sacrifice. From the shady path he descended, performing shan at Mount Li. The rituals mostly adopted what the Grand Invocator used in sacrificing to the Supreme Deity at Yong, but the feng and shan details were all kept secret, so later generations could not record them.

å§‹çš‡ä¹‹ä¸Šæ³°å±±ï¼Œä¸­é˜ªé‡æš´é¢¨é›¨ï¼Œä¼‘æ–¼å¤§æ¨¹ä¸‹ã€‚ è«¸å„’ç”Ÿæ—¢çµ€ï¼Œä¸å¾—èˆ‡ç”¨æ–¼å°äº‹ä¹‹ç¦®ï¼Œèå§‹çš‡é‡é¢¨é›¨ï¼Œå‰‡è­ä¹‹ã€‚
When Shi Huang ascended Mount Tai, midway he encountered violent wind and rain, and rested under a large tree. The Confucian scholars, having been dismissed, could not participate in the feng sacrifice rituals. Hearing that Shi Huang encountered wind and rain, they mocked him.

æ–¼æ˜¯å§‹çš‡é‚æ±éŠæµ·ä¸Šï¼Œè¡Œç¦®ç¥ åå±±å¤§å·åŠå…«ç¥ï¼Œæ±‚åƒŠäººç¾¨é–€ä¹‹å±¬ã€‚ å…«ç¥å°‡è‡ªå¤è€Œæœ‰ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ–æ›°å¤ªå…¬ä»¥ä¾†ä½œä¹‹ã€‚ é½Šæ‰€ä»¥ç‚ºé½Šï¼Œä»¥å¤©é½Šä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶ç¥€çµ•è«çŸ¥èµ·æ™‚ã€‚ å…«ç¥ï¼šä¸€æ›°å¤©ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ å¤©é½Šã€‚ å¤©é½Šæ·µæ°´ï¼Œå±…è‡¨è‘å—éƒŠå±±ä¸‹è€…ã€‚ äºŒæ›°åœ°ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ æ³°å±±æ¢çˆ¶ã€‚ è“‹å¤©å¥½é™°ï¼Œç¥ ä¹‹å¿…æ–¼é«˜å±±ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼Œå°å±±ä¹‹ä¸Šï¼Œå‘½æ›°ã€Œç•¤ã€ï¼› åœ°è²´é™½ï¼Œç¥­ä¹‹å¿…æ–¼æ¾¤ä¸­åœœä¸˜äº‘ã€‚ ä¸‰æ›°å…µä¸»ï¼Œç¥ èš©å°¤ã€‚ èš©å°¤åœ¨æ±å¹³é™¸ç›£é„‰ï¼Œé½Šä¹‹è¥¿å¢ƒä¹Ÿã€‚ å››æ›°é™°ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ä¸‰å±±ã€‚ äº”æ›°é™½ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ä¹‹ç½˜ã€‚ å…­æ›°æœˆä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ä¹‹èŠå±±ã€‚ çš†åœ¨é½ŠåŒ—ï¼Œå¹¶å‹ƒæµ·ã€‚ ä¸ƒæ›°æ—¥ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ æˆå±±ã€‚ æˆå±±æ–—å…¥æµ·ï¼Œæœ€å±…é½Šæ±åŒ—éš…ï¼Œä»¥è¿æ—¥å‡ºäº‘ã€‚ å…«æ›°å››æ™‚ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ç‘¯é‚ªã€‚ ç‘¯é‚ªåœ¨é½Šæ±æ–¹ï¼Œè“‹æ­²ä¹‹æ‰€å§‹ã€‚ çš†å„ç”¨ä¸€ç‰¢å…·ç¥ ï¼Œè€Œå·«ç¥æ‰€æç›Šï¼Œçªå¹£é›œç•°ç„‰ã€‚
Therefore Shi Huang then toured east to the sea, performing rituals and sacrifices to famous mountains, great rivers, and the eight spirits, seeking immortals and the like of Xianmen. The eight spirits have existed since ancient times, some say they were created since the time of Tai Gong. What makes Qi Qi is the heavenly Qi. When its sacrifices ceased, no one knows when they began. The eight spirits: the first is the Heaven Lord, sacrificing to Tian Qi. Tian Qi is a deep pool, located below the mountain in the southern suburbs of Linzi. The second is the Earth Lord, sacrificing at Mount Tai and Mount Li. Heaven prefers shade, so sacrifices to it must be at the foot of high mountains and on top of small mountains, called 'zhi'; earth prefers sunlight, so sacrifices to it must be in round mounds in marshes. The third is the War Lord, sacrificing to Chi You. Chi You is in Dongping Lu Jian Township, the western border of Qi. The fourth is the Yin Lord, sacrificing to the Three Mountains. The fifth is the Yang Lord, sacrificing at Fu. The sixth is the Moon Lord, sacrificing at Mount Lai. All are north of Qi, bordering the Bohai Sea. The seventh is the Sun Lord, sacrificing at Mount Cheng. Mount Cheng thrusts into the sea, located at the northeastern corner of Qi, to welcome the sunrise. The eighth is the Four Seasons Lord, sacrificing at Langye. Langye is in the eastern part of Qi, probably where the year begins. All use one set of sacrificial animals for each sacrifice, but the shamans and invokers made additions and subtractions, with varying jade and silk offerings.

è‡ªé½Šå¨ã€å®£ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œé¨¶å­ä¹‹å¾’è«–è‘—çµ‚å§‹äº”å¾·ä¹‹é‹ï¼ŒåŠç§¦å¸è€Œé½Šäººå¥ä¹‹ï¼Œæ•…å§‹çš‡é‡‡ç”¨ä¹‹ã€‚ è€Œå®‹æ¯‹å¿Œã€æ­£ä¼¯åƒ‘ã€å……å°šã€ç¾¨é–€é«˜æœ€å¾Œçš†ç‡•äººï¼Œç‚ºæ–¹åƒŠé“ï¼Œå½¢è§£éŠ·åŒ–ï¼Œä¾æ–¼é¬¼ç¥ä¹‹äº‹ã€‚ é¨¶è¡ä»¥é™°é™½ä¸»é‹é¡¯æ–¼è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œè€Œç‡•é½Šæµ·ä¸Šä¹‹æ–¹å£«å‚³å…¶è¡“ä¸èƒ½é€šï¼Œç„¶å‰‡æ€ªè¿‚é˜¿è«›èŒåˆä¹‹å¾’è‡ªæ­¤èˆˆï¼Œä¸å¯å‹æ•¸ä¹Ÿã€‚
From the time of Duke Wei and Duke Xuan of Qi, Zou Zi's followers discussed and wrote about the cycles of the beginning and end of the five virtues. When Qin became emperor, the Qi people presented it, so Shi Huang adopted it. Song Wuji, Zheng Boqiao, Chong Shang, Xianmen Gao were the last, all Yan people, practicing the way of immortals, bodily dissolution and transformation, relying on the affairs of ghosts and spirits. Zou Yan became prominent among the feudal lords by mastering yin and yang, and the magicians along the Qi and Yan coasts transmitted his techniques but could not master them thoroughly. Nevertheless, the strange, far-fetched, flattering, and compromising followers arose from this, too numerous to count.

è‡ªå¨ã€å®£ã€ç‡•æ˜­ä½¿äººå…¥æµ·æ±‚è“¬èŠã€æ–¹ä¸ˆã€ç€›æ´²ã€‚ æ­¤ä¸‰ç¥å±±è€…ï¼Œå…¶å‚…åœ¨å‹ƒæµ·ä¸­ï¼Œå»äººä¸é ï¼› æ‚£ä¸”è‡³ï¼Œå‰‡èˆ¹é¢¨å¼•è€Œå»ã€‚ è“‹å˜—æœ‰è‡³è€…ï¼Œè«¸åƒŠäººåŠä¸æ­»ä¹‹è—¥çš†åœ¨ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶ç‰©ç¦½ç¸ç›¡ç™½ï¼Œè€Œé»ƒé‡‘éŠ€ç‚ºå®®é—•ã€‚ æœªè‡³ï¼Œæœ›ä¹‹å¦‚é›²ï¼› åŠåˆ°ï¼Œä¸‰ç¥å±±åå±…æ°´ä¸‹ã€‚ è‡¨ä¹‹ï¼Œé¢¨è¼’å¼•å»ï¼Œçµ‚è«èƒ½è‡³äº‘ã€‚ ä¸–ä¸»è«ä¸ç”˜å¿ƒç„‰ã€‚ åŠè‡³ç§¦å§‹çš‡å¹¶å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œè‡³æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œå‰‡æ–¹å£«è¨€ä¹‹ä¸å¯å‹æ•¸ã€‚ å§‹çš‡è‡ªä»¥ç‚ºè‡³æµ·ä¸Šè€Œæä¸åŠçŸ£ï¼Œä½¿äººä¹ƒé½ç«¥ç”·å¥³å…¥æµ·æ±‚ä¹‹ã€‚ èˆ¹äº¤æµ·ä¸­ï¼Œçš†ä»¥é¢¨ç‚ºè§£ï¼Œæ›°æœªèƒ½è‡³ï¼Œæœ›è¦‹ä¹‹ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶æ˜å¹´ï¼Œå§‹çš‡å¾©æ¸¸æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œè‡³ç‘¯é‚ªï¼Œéæ’å±±ï¼Œå¾ä¸Šé»¨æ­¸ã€‚ å¾Œä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ¸¸ç¢£çŸ³ï¼Œè€ƒå…¥æµ·æ–¹å£«ï¼Œå¾ä¸Šéƒ¡æ­¸ã€‚ å¾Œäº”å¹´ï¼Œå§‹çš‡å—è‡³æ¹˜å±±ï¼Œé‚ç™»æœƒç¨½ï¼Œå¹¶æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œå†€é‡æµ·ä¸­ä¸‰ç¥å±±ä¹‹å¥‡è—¥ã€‚ ä¸å¾—ï¼Œé‚„è‡³æ²™ä¸˜å´©ã€‚
From the time of Wei, Xuan, and Yan Zhao, they sent people into the sea to seek Penglai, Fangzhang, and Yingzhou. These three divine mountains, according to tradition, are in the Bohai Sea, not far from people; but when about to arrive, the wind blows the ships away. It is said that those who have reached them find immortals and medicines of immortality there. Their birds and beasts are all white, and palaces are made of gold and silver. Before arriving, they appear like clouds; when arriving, the three divine mountains sink below the water. When approaching them, the wind always blows them away, and in the end no one can reach them. Every ruler has been devoted to them. When Qin Shi Huang unified the realm and reached the sea, the magicians' words were too numerous to count. Shi Huang considered himself to have reached the sea but feared he might not reach the mountains, so he sent people carrying boys and girls into the sea to seek them. The ships met in the sea, all using wind as an excuse, saying they could not reach them but had glimpsed them. The next year, Shi Huang toured the sea again, reaching Langye, passing Mount Heng, returning from Shangdang. Three years later, he toured Mount Jie, examined the sea-going magicians, returned from Shang Commandery. Five years later, Shi Huang went south to Mount Xiang, then ascended Mount Kuaiji, toured along the sea, hoping to encounter the marvelous medicines of the three divine mountains in the sea. He did not obtain them, and on his return he collapsed at Shaqiu.

äºŒä¸–å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ±å·¡ç¢£çŸ³ï¼Œå¹¶æµ·å—ï¼Œæ­·æ³°å±±ï¼Œè‡³æœƒç¨½ï¼Œçš†ç¦®ç¥ ä¹‹ï¼Œè€Œåˆ»å‹’å§‹çš‡æ‰€ç«‹çŸ³æ›¸æ—ï¼Œä»¥ç« å§‹çš‡ä¹‹åŠŸå¾·ã€‚ å…¶ç§‹ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯ç•”ç§¦ã€‚ ä¸‰å¹´è€ŒäºŒä¸–å¼’æ­»ã€‚
In the first year of the Second Emperor, he toured east to Mount Jie, toured south of the sea, passed Mount Tai, reached Mount Kuaiji, all performing rituals and sacrifices, and carved beside the stone inscriptions Shi Huang had erected, to proclaim Shi Huang's achievements and virtue. That autumn, the feudal lords rebelled against Qin. After three years, the Second Emperor was assassinated and died.

å§‹çš‡å°ç¦ªä¹‹å¾ŒåäºŒæ­²ï¼Œç§¦äº¡ã€‚ è«¸å„’ç”Ÿç–¾ç§¦ç„šè©©æ›¸ï¼Œèª…åƒ‡æ–‡å­¸ï¼Œç™¾å§“æ€¨å…¶æ³•ï¼Œå¤©ä¸‹ç•”ä¹‹ï¼Œçš†è¨›æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹çš‡ä¸Šæ³°å±±ï¼Œç‚ºæš´é¢¨é›¨æ‰€æ“Šï¼Œä¸å¾—å°ç¦ªã€‚ã€ æ­¤è±ˆæ‰€è¬‚ç„¡å…¶å¾·è€Œç”¨äº‹è€…é‚ªï¼Ÿ
Twelve years after Shi Huang's feng and shan sacrifices, Qin perished. The Confucian scholars resented Qin for burning the poems and books, slaughtering the literati, and the people resented their laws, so the realm rebelled against them, all falsely saying: 'Shi Huang ascended Mount Tai, was struck by violent wind and rain, could not perform the feng and shan.' Is this not what is called performing the rituals without possessing virtue?

æ˜”ä¸‰ä»£ä¹‹ï¼ˆå›ï¼‰ï¼»å±…ï¼½çš†åœ¨æ²³æ´›ä¹‹é–’ï¼Œæ•…åµ©é«˜ç‚ºä¸­å¶½ï¼Œè€Œå››å¶½å„å¦‚å…¶æ–¹ï¼Œå››ç€†å’¸åœ¨å±±æ±ã€‚ è‡³ç§¦ç¨±å¸ï¼Œéƒ½å’¸é™½ï¼Œå‰‡äº”å¶½ã€å››ç€†çš†å¹¶åœ¨æ±æ–¹ã€‚ è‡ªäº”å¸ä»¥è‡³ç§¦ï¼Œè»¼èˆˆè»¼è¡°ï¼Œåå±±å¤§å·æˆ–åœ¨è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œæˆ–åœ¨å¤©å­ï¼Œå…¶ç¦®æç›Šä¸–æ®Šï¼Œä¸å¯å‹è¨˜ã€‚ åŠç§¦å¹¶å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œä»¤ç¥ å®˜æ‰€å¸¸å¥‰å¤©åœ°åå±±å¤§å·é¬¼ç¥å¯å¾—è€Œåºä¹Ÿã€‚
In ancient times, the capitals of the Three Dynasties were all between the Yellow River and Luo River, so Mount Song was the central peak, and the four peaks were each in their directions, and the four rivers were all east of the mountains. When Qin declared itself emperor and made Xianyang the capital, then the five peaks and four rivers were all in the east. From the Five Emperors to Qin, dynasties rose and declined alternately, famous mountains and great rivers were sometimes in the feudal lords' territories, sometimes in the Son of Heaven's domain, their rituals increased and decreased with each generation, impossible to record completely. When Qin unified the realm, they ordered the sacrificial officials to constantly maintain the sacrifices to heaven, earth, famous mountains, great rivers, and ghosts and spirits that could be properly ordered.

Therefore, east of Xiao, five famous mountains and two great rivers were sacrificed to. Called Tai Shi. Tai Shi is Mount Song. Mount Heng, Mount Tai, Mount Kuaiji, Mount Xiang. Rivers called Ji, called Huai. In spring they used dried meat and wine for the annual sacrifice, when the ice broke up; in autumn when water dried up; in winter for blocked prayers and sacrifices. Their sacrificial animals used one calf each, with varying pens, jade, and silk.

è‡ªè¯ä»¥è¥¿ï¼Œåå±±ä¸ƒï¼Œåå·å››ã€‚ æ›°è¯å±±ï¼Œè–„å±±ã€‚ è–„å±±è€…ï¼Œè¡°å±±ä¹Ÿã€‚ å²³å±±ï¼Œå²å±±ï¼Œå³å²³ï¼Œé´»å†¢ï¼Œç€†å±±ã€‚ ç€†å±±ï¼Œèœ€ä¹‹æ±¶å±±ã€‚ æ°´æ›°æ²³ï¼Œç¥ è‡¨æ™‰ï¼› æ²”ï¼Œç¥ æ¼¢ä¸­ï¼› æ¹«æ·µï¼Œç¥ æœé‚£ï¼› æ±Ÿæ°´ï¼Œç¥ èœ€ã€‚ äº¦æ˜¥ç§‹æ³®æ¶¸ç¦±å¡ï¼Œå¦‚æ±æ–¹åå±±å·ï¼› è€Œç‰²ç‰›çŠ¢ç‰¢å…·çªå¹£å„ç•°ã€‚ è€Œå››å¤§å†¢é´»ã€å²ã€å³ã€å²³ï¼Œçš†æœ‰å˜—ç¦¾ã€‚
West of Mount Hua, seven famous mountains and four famous rivers. Called Mount Hua, Mount Bo. Mount Bo is Mount Wei. Mount Yue, Mount Qi, Mount Wu, Mount Hongzhong, Mount Du. Mount Du is Shu's Mount Min. Rivers called the Yellow River, sacrificed at Linjin; Mian, sacrificed at Hanzhong; Jiao Abyss, sacrificed at Zhaona; Yangtze River, sacrificed at Shu. Also in spring they break up ice, in autumn dry up water, in winter blocked prayers and sacrifices, like the eastern famous mountains and rivers; and the sacrificial animals were calves, with varying pens, jade, and silk. And the four great tombs Hong, Qi, Wu, Yue, all had autumn grain sacrifices.

é™³å¯¶ç¯€ä¾†ç¥ ã€‚ å…¶æ²³åŠ æœ‰å˜—é†ªã€‚ æ­¤çš†åœ¨é›å·ä¹‹åŸŸï¼Œè¿‘å¤©å­ä¹‹éƒ½ï¼Œæ•…åŠ è»Šä¸€ä¹˜ï¼Œé¨®é§’å››ã€‚
Chen Bao had seasonal sacrifices. The Yellow River additionally had autumn wine sacrifices. These were all in Yong province's domain, near the Son of Heaven's capital, so they added one carriage, four sorrel horses.

Ba, Chan, Changshui, Yong, Lao, Jing, Wei were not great rivers, but because they were near Xianyang, they all received mountain and river sacrifices, without additional offerings.

The two abysses of Qian and Luo, Mingze, Pushan, Yuexushan and others were small mountains and rivers, and all had annual prayers and sacrifices for blockages, ice breaking, and water drying, but the rituals were not necessarily the same.

Yong had more than a hundred temples for the sun, moon, Can, Shen, northern and southern dippers, Yinghuo, Taibai, Suixing, Tianshen, the twenty-eight constellations, wind lord, rain master, four seas, nine ministers, fourteen ministers, various spreading spirits, various strict spirits, various seeking spirits, and others. The west also had several dozen sacrifices. At the lake there was a temple for the Zhou Son of Heaven. At Xia Gui there was a heaven spirit. Yong and Chen had Zhao Ming and the Son of Heaven's secluded pool. At Du and Bo there were sacrifices to the three altar lords and the longevity star; and Yong's Jian temple also had a Du lord. The Du lord was formerly Zhou's right general, and among Qin spirits, he was the least significant. Each was sacrificed to according to the seasons.

å”¯é›å››ç•¤ä¸Šå¸ç‚ºå°Šï¼Œå…¶å…‰æ™¯å‹•äººæ°‘å”¯é™³å¯¶ã€‚ æ•…é›å››ç•¤ï¼Œæ˜¥ä»¥ç‚ºæ­²ç¦±ï¼Œå› æ³®å‡ï¼Œç§‹æ¶¸å‡ï¼Œå†¬å¡ç¥ ï¼Œäº”æœˆå˜—é§’ï¼ŒåŠå››ä»²ä¹‹æœˆï¼ˆç¥ è‹¥ï¼‰æœˆç¥ ï¼Œï¼»è‹¥ï¼½é™³å¯¶ç¯€ä¾†ä¸€ç¥ ã€‚ æ˜¥å¤ç”¨é¨‚ï¼Œç§‹å†¬ç”¨é§µã€‚ ç•¤é§’å››åŒ¹ï¼Œæœ¨ç¦ºé¾æ¬’è»Šä¸€é§Ÿï¼Œæœ¨ç¦ºè»Šé¦¬ä¸€é§Ÿï¼Œå„å¦‚å…¶å¸è‰²ã€‚ é»ƒçŠ¢ç¾”å„å››ï¼Œçªå¹£å„æœ‰æ•¸ï¼Œçš†ç”Ÿç˜åŸ‹ï¼Œç„¡ä¿è±†ä¹‹å…·ã€‚ ä¸‰å¹´ä¸€éƒŠã€‚ ç§¦ä»¥å†¬åæœˆç‚ºæ­²é¦–ï¼Œæ•…å¸¸ä»¥åæœˆä¸Šå®¿éƒŠè¦‹ï¼Œé€šæ¬Šç«ï¼Œæ‹œæ–¼å’¸é™½ä¹‹æ—ï¼Œè€Œè¡£ä¸Šç™½ï¼Œå…¶ç”¨å¦‚ç¶“ç¥ äº‘ã€‚ è¥¿ç•¤ã€ç•¦ç•¤ï¼Œç¥ å¦‚å…¶æ•…ï¼Œä¸Šä¸è¦ªå¾€ã€‚
Only Yong's four altars to the Supreme Deity were most honored, and what moved the people most was Chen Bao. Therefore Yong's four altars: in spring they made annual prayers, when ice broke up; in autumn when water dried; in winter for blocked sacrifices; in the fifth month they tasted colts; and in the four mid-months they sacrificed if it was the month, and if Chen Bao's season came, they sacrificed once. In spring and summer they used red horses, in autumn and winter they used black horses. Altar colts were four horses each, wooden dragon-ornamented carriages one team, wooden carriages and horses one team each, each matching their emperor's color. Yellow calves and lambs four each, jade and silk each had numbers, all buried alive, without sacrificial stands and vessels. Once every three years for suburban sacrifices. Qin made the tenth month of winter the year's beginning, so they constantly used the tenth month to lodge at the altar and see the suburban sacrifice, passed through Quan fire, bowed beside Xianyang, and wore upper white, their usage was like the regular sacrifices. The western altar and qi altar were sacrificed to as before, the emperor did not personally go.

è«¸æ­¤ç¥ çš†å¤ªç¥å¸¸ä¸»ï¼Œä»¥æ­²æ™‚å¥‰ç¥ ä¹‹ã€‚ è‡³å¦‚ä»–åå±±å·è«¸é¬¼åŠå…«ç¥ä¹‹å±¬ï¼Œä¸Šéå‰‡ç¥ ï¼Œå»å‰‡å·²ã€‚ éƒ¡ç¸£é æ–¹ç¥ç¥ è€…ï¼Œæ°‘å„è‡ªå¥‰ç¥ ï¼Œä¸é ˜æ–¼å¤©å­ä¹‹ç¥å®˜ã€‚ ç¥å®˜æœ‰ç¥•ç¥ï¼Œå³æœ‰è‘ç¥¥ï¼Œè¼’ç¥ç¥ ç§»éæ–¼ä¸‹ã€‚
All these sacrifices were constantly overseen by the grand invocator, who sacrificed to them according to the seasons. As for other famous mountains, rivers, various ghosts, and the eight spirits, when the emperor passed by he sacrificed, when he left he stopped. Sacrifices to gods of distant commanderies and counties were maintained by the people themselves, not overseen by the Son of Heaven's invocator officials. The invocator officials had secret prayers, and when there were calamities or good omens, they immediately prayed and transferred them downward.

æ¼¢èˆˆï¼Œé«˜ç¥–ä¹‹å¾®æ™‚ï¼Œå˜—æ®ºå¤§è›‡ã€‚ æœ‰ç‰©æ›°ï¼šã€Œè›‡ï¼Œç™½å¸å­ä¹Ÿï¼Œè€Œæ®ºè€…èµ¤å¸å­ã€‚ã€ é«˜ç¥–åˆèµ·ï¼Œç¦±è±æŒæ¦†ç¤¾ã€‚ å¾‡æ²›ï¼Œç‚ºæ²›å…¬ï¼Œå‰‡ç¥ èš©å°¤ï¼Œé‡é¼“æ——ã€‚ é‚ä»¥åæœˆè‡³çä¸Šï¼Œèˆ‡è«¸ä¾¯å¹³å’¸é™½ï¼Œç«‹ç‚ºæ¼¢ç‹ã€‚ å› ä»¥åæœˆç‚ºå¹´é¦–ï¼Œè€Œè‰²ä¸Šèµ¤ã€‚
When Han arose, during Gaozu's humble times, he once killed a large snake. There was a voice that said: 'The snake is the White Emperor's son, but the killer is the Red Emperor's son.' When Gaozu first rose up, he prayed at the Fengfen Yu Altar. When he toured Pei, became Duke of Pei, he sacrificed to Chi You, smeared blood on drums and flags. He then arrived at Bashang in the tenth month, pacified Xianyang with the feudal lords, and was established as King of Han. Therefore he made the tenth month the year's beginning, and took red as the superior color.

In the second year, he attacked Xiang Ji eastward and returned, entering the passes, asked: 'What emperor did the former Qin sacrifice to the Supreme Deity?' They answered: 'Four emperors, there were sacrifices to the White, Blue, Yellow, Red emperors.' Gaozu said: 'I have heard heaven has five emperors, but there are four, why is that?' No one knew the explanation. Therefore Gaozu said: 'I understand it now, they were waiting for me to complete the five.' He then established the Black Emperor sacrifice, named it the Northern Altar. The officials conducted the sacrifice, the emperor did not personally go. He summoned all the former Qin invocator officials, restored the grand invocator and grand steward, following their former ceremonies and rituals. He ordered the counties to establish public altars. He issued an edict saying: 'I greatly value sacrifices and respect offerings. Now the sacrifices to the Supreme Deity and the various mountain and river spirits that should be sacrificed to, each will be sacrificed to according to their times and rituals as before.'

Four years later, when the realm was already settled, he commanded the censor to order Feng to carefully maintain the Fen Yu Altar, constantly sacrificing to it in the four seasons, in spring using pigs and sheep. He ordered the invocator officials to establish Chi You's sacrifice in Chang'an. Chang'an established invocator officials and female shamans. The Liang shamans sacrificed to heaven, earth, heavenly altar, heavenly water, inner chambers, halls above, and others; the Jin shamans sacrificed to the five emperors, eastern lord, cloud middle lord, destiny master, shaman altar, shaman temple, clansmen, first cooks, and others; the Qin shamans sacrificed to the altar lord, shaman protector, clan multitudes, and others; the Jing shamans sacrificed to hall below, shaman ancestors, destiny master, spreading spirits, and others; the nine heaven shamans sacrificed to the nine heavens: all sacrificed in the palace according to the seasons. The river shamans sacrificed to the river at Linjin, and the southern mountain shamans sacrificed to the southern mountains in Qin central. Qin central refers to the Second Emperor. Each had its time and day.

Two years later, some said that when Zhou arose they settled in Tai, established Hou Ji's sacrifice, and to this day receive blood sacrifices throughout the realm. Therefore Gaozu issued an edict to the censor: 'Order the commanderies, kingdoms, and counties to establish the spirit star sacrifice, constantly sacrificing to it with oxen according to the seasons.'

Eighteen years later, Emperor Wen ascended the throne. In his thirteenth year of reign, he issued an edict saying: 'Now the secret prayers transfer calamities downward, I greatly disapprove. From now on, abolish them.'

æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œåˆ¶æ›°ï¼šã€Œæœ•å³ä½åä¸‰å¹´äºä»Šï¼Œè³´å®—å»Ÿä¹‹éˆï¼Œç¤¾ç¨·ä¹‹ç¦ï¼Œæ–¹å…§è‰¾å®‰ï¼Œæ°‘äººé¡ç–¾ã€‚ é–’è€…æ¯”å¹´ç™»ï¼Œæœ•ä¹‹ä¸å¾·ï¼Œä½•ä»¥é¥—æ­¤ï¼Ÿ çš†ä¸Šå¸è«¸ç¥ä¹‹è³œä¹Ÿã€‚ è“‹èå¤è€…é¥—å…¶å¾·å¿…å ±å…¶åŠŸï¼Œæ¬²æœ‰å¢è«¸ç¥ç¥ ã€‚ æœ‰å¸è­°å¢é›äº”ç•¤è·¯è»Šå„ä¸€ä¹˜ï¼Œé§•è¢«å…·ï¼› è¥¿ç•¤ç•¦ç•¤ç¦ºè»Šå„ä¸€ä¹˜ï¼Œç¦ºé¦¬å››åŒ¹ï¼Œé§•è¢«å…·ï¼› å…¶æ²³ã€æ¹«ã€æ¼¢æ°´åŠ ç‰å„äºŒï¼› åŠè«¸ç¥ ï¼Œå„å¢å»£å£‡å ´ï¼Œçªå¹£ä¿è±†ä»¥å·®åŠ ä¹‹ã€‚ è€Œç¥ç¥•è€…æ­¸ç¦æ–¼æœ•ï¼Œç™¾å§“ä¸èˆ‡ç„‰ã€‚ è‡ªä»Šç¥è‡´æ•¬ï¼Œæ¯‹æœ‰æ‰€ç¥ˆã€‚ã€
That year, the edict said: 'I have now been on the throne thirteen years, relying on the ancestral temples' spirits and the altars' blessings, the realm within the borders is peaceful, the people have no illnesses. Recently there have been good harvests for several years, due to my lack of virtue, how can I enjoy this? It is all the Supreme Deity and various spirits' blessings. I have heard that in ancient times, those who enjoyed virtue necessarily repaid merit, and wish to increase the sacrifices to the various spirits. The officials discussed increasing Yong's five altars by one road carriage each, with harnesses and coverings; the western altar and qi altar by one wooden carriage each, four wooden horses, with harnesses and coverings; the Yellow River, Jiao, Han River to add two pieces of jade each; and for the various sacrifices, each to broaden the altar grounds, adding jade, silk, sacrificial stands, and vessels according to rank. The praying invocators should return blessings to me, the people should not participate. From now on, when praying, show respect, do not make any requests.'

The Lu man Gongsun Chen submitted a memorial saying: 'At first Qin obtained water virtue, now Han receives it, following the cycles of beginning and end transmission, then Han should be earth virtue, the response to earth virtue is yellow dragons appearing. We should correct the calendar, change the clothing colors, take yellow as the superior color.' At this time Chancellor Zhang Cang liked laws and calendars, believing Han was the beginning of water virtue, so the river breaking the golden dike was its omen. The year began in winter's tenth month, color was black outside and red inside, matching the virtue. Gongsun Chen's words were not correct. He dismissed him. Three years later, a yellow dragon appeared at Chengji. Emperor Wen then summoned Gongsun Chen, appointed him as a doctor, and with the various scholars drafted matters of changing the calendar and clothing colors. That summer, he issued an edict saying: 'Strange spiritual objects have appeared at Chengji, without harming the people, the year has good harvests. I pray at the suburban sacrifices to the Supreme Deity and various spirits, the ritual officials discuss, do not avoid laboring me.' All the officials said: 'In ancient times the Son of Heaven personally performed the summer suburban sacrifice, sacrificing to the Supreme Deity in the suburbs, hence called suburban.' Therefore in summer's fourth month, Emperor Wen began the suburban audience, sacrificing at Yong's five altars, all clothing was upper red.

In summer's fourth month, Emperor Wen personally bowed at the Ba Wei gathering, performing suburban audience at Wei Yang's five emperors. The next year, the present emperor first went to Yong, performed suburban audience at the five altars. Afterward he constantly performed suburban sacrifices once every three years. At this time Li Shaojun also appeared before the emperor using methods of sacrificing to the stove, grain immortals, and anti-aging, the emperor honored him. Shaojun was formerly a retainer of the Marquis of Shenze, mastered techniques. He concealed his age and growth, constantly claimed to be seventy, could make things appear, and reverse aging. He traveled among the feudal lords using his techniques. He had no wife or children. People heard of his ability to make things appear and not die, so they sent him gifts, he constantly had surplus gold, money, clothing, and food. People all thought he did not manage livelihood but was wealthy, and moreover did not know where he came from, believed him even more, competed to serve him. Shaojun was fond of techniques, good at making skillful predictions that strangely hit the mark. He once drank with the Marquis of Wuan, there was a ninety-year-old man in the seats, Shaojun spoke of places he had hunted and shot with his grandfather, the old man as a child had followed his grandfather, recognized the places, the whole gathering was astonished. Shaojun saw the emperor, the emperor had an old bronze vessel, asked Shaojun. Shaojun said: 'This vessel Duke Huan of Qi placed in the Bo Resting Hall in his tenth year.' The Bo man Miu Ji memorialized sacrificing to Tai Yi, saying: 'Among the heavenly spirits, the most honored is Tai Yi, Tai Yi's assistants are called the Five Emperors. Therefore the emperor ordered the grand invocator to establish his sacrifice in Chang'an's southeastern suburbs, constantly maintaining the sacrifice according to Ji's methods. Afterward someone submitted a memorial saying: 'In ancient times the Son of Heaven once every three years used great sacrificial animals to sacrifice to the Three Ones: Heaven One, Earth One, Tai One.' The emperor approved it, ordered the grand invocator to oversee sacrificing to them on Ji's Tai Yi altar, according to his methods. Later someone again submitted a memorial saying: 'In ancient times the Son of Heaven constantly used spring to release sacrifices, sacrificing to the Yellow Emperor used one owl broken mirror; the Dark Sheep used sheep to sacrifice; the Horse Walk used one blue stallion; Tai Yi, Ze Mountain Lord, Earth Chief used oxen; Wu Yi Lord used dried fish; Yin Yang messengers used one ox.' The next year, the Qi man Shao Wen appeared before the emperor using ghost and spirit techniques. The year after Wencheng died, the emperor fell seriously ill at Ding Lake, shamans and physicians were all summoned, but he did not recover. You Shui Fa Gen said Shang Commandery had a shaman who fell ill and ghosts and spirits descended to her. The emperor summoned and established sacrifices to her at Ganquan. When he fell ill, he sent people to ask the divine lord. The divine lord said: 'The emperor need not worry about illness. When illness improves a little, force yourself to meet me at Ganquan.' Therefore the illness improved, he arose, went to Ganquan, the illness was completely cured. He granted a great amnesty, established the Shou Palace divine lord. The Shou Palace divine lord's most honored was Tai Yi, her assistants called Da Jin, Si Ming and others, all followed her. She could not be seen, people heard her words, her words were like human speech. Sometimes left, sometimes came, when she came the wind was solemn. She resided in the chamber curtains. Sometimes spoke by day, but usually at night. The emperor purified himself, then entered. Therefore they used the shaman as host, shut the doors to food and drink. What she said, was carried out below. He also established the Shou Palace and North Palace, spread feathered banners, set up offerings, to honor the divine lord. What the divine lord said, the emperor sent people to receive and record her words in writing, named it 'painting method.' What she discussed was what common people knew, nothing extraordinarily different, but the emperor was uniquely pleased in his heart. The matters were secret, the world did not know them.

That spring, the Marquis of Lecheng submitted a memorial about Luan Da. Luan Da was a Qi palace attendant, formerly studied with General Wencheng, afterward became the alchemist for King Shang of Qi. The Marquis of Lecheng's sister was Queen Kang, had no sons. King Kang died, another consort's son was established as king. Queen Kang had lewd conduct, did not get along with the king, they endangered each other according to law. Queen Kang heard Wencheng had died, wished to flatter the emperor herself, sent Luan Da through the Marquis of Lecheng to seek audience and speak of techniques. The emperor had executed Wencheng, afterward regretted his early death, pitied his techniques were not exhausted, when he saw Luan Da, was greatly pleased. Da was tall and handsome, spoke many strategies, and dared make great claims without doubt. Da said: 'I constantly travel in the sea, see An Qi, Xianmen and others. But they consider me lowly, do not trust me. Also consider King Kang just a feudal lord, not worth giving techniques to. I frequently spoke to King Kang, King Kang also did not use me. My teacher said: 'Gold can be made, river breaches can be blocked, immortality medicine can be obtained, immortals can be summoned.' But I fear suffering Wencheng's fate, then all magicians will shut their mouths, who would dare speak of techniques!' The emperor said: 'Wencheng died from eating horse liver. If you can truly perfect his techniques, what would I begrudge!' Da said: 'My teacher does not seek people, people seek him. If Your Majesty truly wishes to summon him, then honor his envoy, let him have relatives, treat him with guest rituals, do not demean him, make each wear their trust seal, then can make him communicate with divine people. Divine people still might accept or not. Make his envoy honored, then he can be summoned.' Therefore the emperor tested small techniques, fighting chess pieces, the chess pieces fought each other.

At this time the emperor was worried about river breaches, and gold was not completed, so he appointed Da as Five Profits General. Therefore the emperor carved a jade seal saying 'Heavenly Dao General', sent envoys wearing feathered robes, standing on white thatch at night, Five Profits General also wore feathered robes, stood on white thatch at night to receive the seal, to show not being subjects. That summer in the sixth month, Fen Yin shaman Jin sacrificed to Hou Tu for the people beside Wei Zhi camp, saw ground like a hook shape, dug and inspected, obtained a ding. The ding greatly differed from common dings, patterned and engraved without inscriptions, considered it strange, reported to officials. Officials told Hedong governor Sheng, Sheng reported it. The emperor sent envoys to verify the shaman obtained the ding without fraud, then sacrificed with rites, welcomed the ding to Ganquan, followed along, the emperor offered it. Arriving at Zhongshan, it was warm and sunny, there was yellow cloud cover. A muntjac passed, the emperor personally shot it, used it to sacrifice. Arriving at Chang'an, the dukes and ministers all discussed requesting to honor the precious ding. The emperor said: 'Recently the river overflowed, years had poor harvests, so I toured and sacrificed to Hou Tu, prayed for the people to grow grain. Now the year has abundant harvests not yet repaid, why did the ding emerge?' All officials said: 'Heard that formerly Tai Di raised one divine ding, one means unified, the end where heaven, earth, ten thousand things are tied. Huang Di made three precious dings, resembling heaven, earth, man. Yu collected nine provinces' metal, cast nine dings. All once cooked and offered to the Supreme Deity and ghosts and spirits. When sages encountered them they rose, dings moved to Xia and Shang. Zhou virtue declined, Song's altar perished, dings then sank and disappeared, hidden and unseen. The ode says 'From hall to foundation, from sheep to oxen; great dings and small cauldrons, not noisy not arrogant, how examine their good fortune.' Now ding arrives at Ganquan, bright and lustrous dragon transformations, receiving good fortune without bound. Meets at Zhongshan, yellow white clouds descend covering, like beasts as symbols, road bows multiplied arrows, gathered obtained below the altar, report sacrifice great enjoyment. Only those who receive the mandate and become emperors know its intention and match virtue. The ding should appear at ancestral temples, stored in imperial courts, to match bright responses.' Edict said: 'Approved.'

That autumn, the emperor went to Yong, about to perform suburban sacrifice. Some said 'The Five Emperors are Tai Yi's assistants, should establish Tai Yi and the emperor personally perform suburban sacrifice to him.' The emperor was doubtful and undecided. The Qi man Gongsun Qing said: 'This year obtained precious ding, this winter Xin Si new moon dawn winter solstice, equals Huang Di's time.' Qing had bamboo slips book saying: 'Huang Di obtained precious ding at Wan Qu, asked Gui Yu Qu. Gui Yu Qu answered: 'Huang Di obtained precious ding divine strategy, this year Ji You new moon dawn winter solstice, obtained heaven's cycle, end and begin again.' Therefore Huang Di welcomed the sun and pushed the strategy, afterward led twenty years again new moon dawn winter solstice, altogether twenty pushes, three hundred eighty years, Huang Di became immortal and ascended to heaven.' Qing through Shou Zhong wished to memorialize it. Shou Zhong saw the book was not orthodox, suspected it false writing, apologized saying: 'Precious ding matter already decided, what more to do!' Qing through favored people memorialized it. The emperor was greatly pleased, summoned and questioned Qing. Answered: 'Received this book from Shen Gong, Shen Gong already died.' The emperor said: 'Who is Shen Gong?' Qing said: 'Shen Gong is a Qi man. Communicated with An Qisheng, received Huang Di's words, no book, only has this ding book. Says 'Han rise should again be like Huang Di's time'. Says 'Han sage will be in Gaozu's grandson and great-grandson. Precious ding emerges and communicates with spirits, perform feng and shan. Feng and shan seventy-two kings, only Huang Di could ascend Mount Tai for feng.' Shen Gong said: 'Han ruler also should ascend for feng, ascending for feng can become immortal and ascend to heaven. Huang Di's time had ten thousand feudal lords, divine spirits' feng dwellers seven thousand. Realm's famous mountains eight, three in barbarian Yi, five in central states. Central states' Mount Hua, Shou Mountain, Tai Shi, Mount Tai, Donglai, these five mountains Huang Di constantly toured, met with spirits. Huang Di fought and studied immortality. Worried the people were not following the way, then beheaded those who defied ghosts and spirits. Over a hundred years then could communicate with spirits. Huang Di performed suburban sacrifice to Supreme Deity at Yong, stayed three months. Gui Yu Qu was titled Great Hong, died buried at Yong, so Hong Tomb is it. Afterward Huang Di received ten thousand spirits at Bright Court. Bright Court is Ganquan. So-called Cold Gate is Valley Mouth. Huang Di gathered Shou Mountain copper, cast ding below Jing Mountain. Ding completed, dragon hung beard down welcoming Huang Di. Huang Di mounted, group ministers and rear palace followers who ascended seventy plus people, dragon then departed upward. Remaining small ministers could not ascend, all held dragon beard, dragon beard pulled out, fell, fell Huang Di's bow. People gazed up at Huang Di already ascended to heaven, embraced his bow and beard crying, so later generations named the place Ding Lake, his bow Wu Hao.' Therefore the emperor said: 'Alas! If I can truly be like Huang Di, I would view leaving wife and children like removing shoes.' He appointed Qing as gentleman, sent east to wait for spirits at Tai Shi.
